As I know to my cost—because, like the hon. Member for Droylsden (Mr. W. R. Williams), I was wiped out in the last redistribution and I know what he feels—we then lost 18 seats in London. Now we are to lose another—not because we do not have sufficient people to support 43 Members, for we do have them. Even on the restricted basis which the Commissioners took for calculating their figures, in London we are only half a Member short of that to which they say we are strictly entitled.
Instead of leaving the situation alone and stopping the nonsense of fiddling around with constituencies in the absurd way described by my three hon. Friends, the Commission has chopped off another Member. Other changes then have to be made—they come up on the next Order—to justify changes which seem to be utterly absurd and which will seriously prejudice the business organisation of the next L.C.C. elections which are due at the end of next March.
It is never easy to build up new political organisations in new constituencies. It is not easy for local authorities who run the business side of an election. But to be told to do it in less than two months of election day is asking for a lot of inevitable confusion when the election comes along, especially in this case when a county council constituency is the same as the Parliamentary and will be in two boroughs with two town clerks and two returning officers. I know that it is said that it can be sorted out. Of course it can, but it is all adding unnecessary work to the business of conducting an election in this great London of ours.
I do not understand why the Government, who have looked at this matter with an open mind, could not have said, as has been said before on this kind of occasion, "There is nothing very much in the proposal to justify a change in London constituencies and we will drop it." The case for not altering the constituencies in London rests entirely on its own merits and need not be affected in any way by what occurs in the rest of the country. It is a little bit absurd.
I remind the House that the political organisations in London have been against the proposal throughout. I miss perhaps one Conservative Member who has been sitting waiting for this debate. It may be—I do not know—that as a
result of the changes which the Commission made in its first proposal before submitting the ones we are now discussing all the Conservative Members escaped without interference and the only people interfered with happened to be Labour Members. That is what has happened, and if some people draw unkind conclusions as to why that was done, it will be quite natural. If Conservative Members who represent London constituencies really believe that they represent the people in their districts in these matters they should vote with us against the Order and against the next one, affecting Fulham and Hammersmith.
There has been a completely unanimous opinion on the part of the political parties, the borough councils, the London County Council and the Metropolitan Boroughs Standing Joint Committee, which is the organisation representing the borough councils for practical working purposes. If ever there was a case where there was unanimity of opinion that the proposals of the Commission were wrong, this certainly is it. If there is a Division—and the Minister could avoid it by saying that he would withdraw the Order—we should see all the Conservative Members for London seats in the Lobby with us protesting against something being done which will hamper and hinder the political and electoral development of London, which will create for us in the next two or three months difficulties in the London County Council elections and which will be unfair to the people of London.

One feature which has struck me during the fairly long debates that we have had yesterday and today, most of which I have heard, has been the number of hon. Gentlemen who have asked that no change at all should be made.
There is a case for it this time.

We are discussing Order for the redistribution of seats. Where no changes are suggested no Orders are submitted. Where changes are suggested that is bound to cause inconvenience in some cases. I do not see how it could be avoided. There are bound to be difficulties here and there.
What is the basis of any suggestion for redistribution which this House has laid
down? There are various methods. I fancy that on the whole two considerations would count here. There is the size of one of the constituencies. It has an electorate of 81,500 plus, which one hon. Gentleman referred to as a magic figure. It may be a magic figure because 80,000 was the figure decided upon by this House. The other thing the House decided, and it is in one of the Rules, is that the Commissioners must bear in mind, when coming to a decision, the disparity in figures and particularly the disparity in relation to adjacent constituencies.
That is a nonsensical one.
It may be nonsensical, but so nonsensical that it was supported by hon. Members opposite, who passed it into law.

It is nonsensical because in the rest of London the same position applies and it is not being altered. If the right hon. and gallant Gentleman puts forward that this happens in Bethnal Green because it happens to be a smaller constituency next to large ones, why was it not done in other cases of the same kind?

The hon. Member may have in mind a place alongside the river which, if added to the next constituency, would be well over the figure of 80,000, the figure which was laid down. I suggest with all sincerity to hon. Members that, the House having accepted that criterion, it is difficult to find a case more deserving of treatment than this. Here we have three constituencies which are adjacent, one with an electorate of 40,000, the next with 75,000—in round figures—and the other with 81,000. If we put the three together we get electorates of 63,000, 67,000 and 66,000.
The Rule also says that borough boundaries should not overlap and this is an excessive case of overlapping borough boundaries.

That case has been made before, but I would draw attention to the specific exception put in Rule 5:
and a boundary commission may depart from the strict application of the last foregoing rule…"— which is the one to which the hon. Member referred— if it appears that a departure is desirable to avoid an excessive disparity between the electorate of any constituency and the electorate quota… It is definite there. or between the electorate thereof and that of neighbouring constituencies in the part of the United Kingdom with which they are concerned.
Why should the Minister say that we may depart from one Rule but not from another? He seems to regard 80,000 as the magic figure, yet there we have a Rule which he completely disregards.

I have read the part which seemed to me to make perfectly clear that in certain circumstances the Commission is entitled by the wish of this House to depart from that particular Rule. There can be no doubt at all that in this instance it has departed from it and, I think, rightly departed from it. Some hon. Members think it better to leave the position as it is, but the Act lays down that in a certain period of years reviews have to be made and lays down Rules to be applied in carrying out the reviews.

If the right hon. and Gallant Gentleman is concerned with getting a solution to the problem of a large constituency next to a small one, why not apply the principle of making three constituencies out of Stoke Newington and the large borough of Hackney. with an electorate of 121,000?

It seems to me that in this case the Commission has made a recommendation in complete accord with the wishes of this House. [An HON. MEMBER: "Why not answer the question? "] It is no good hon. Members saying that I do not answer questions. Hon. Gentlemen opposite are constantly trying to avoid the fruits of the Act for which they are responsible. I am only recommending to the House what to do.
In that case, we do not need the right hon. and gallant Gentleman. We should have the Commissioners here.

That was not the intention of Parliament. As it happens, the House has given the Commissioners a duty to perform, and it is the job of the Home Secretary to place the orders, made as a consequence of the Commissioners' recommendations, before the House. There is no modification in this instance. On the previous occasion they were modified afterwards.
There were no orders then.

I know; they became part of the Schedule.
We are discussing something in which I do not think that the Commissioners have departed from what the House intended they should do. It was accepted by hon. Members opposite. But when it comes to putting it into operation, what happens? I am not complaining, because, obviously, hon. Members do not want their constituencies interfered with, but the purpose of the Act is to interfere with the constituencies. That is its purpose.
The vast majority of constituencies have not been interfered with at all. It is only in such cases as this that changes have been recommended, and I challenge anyone to give a more glaring example of inequality as regards electoral average.
Mr. Weitzman rose—

Let me finish.
I should have thought—and I have not the slightest desire to score a point on this—that here, if anywhere, discrepancies are to be found. The hon. Gentleman asked why an inquiry had not been held. It is not for me to order the Commission to hold an inquiry. By law, it is entirely at the discretion of the Commission whether or not it holds an inquiry. It would be most improper for any Home Secretary to interfere with that discretion.
As far as London generally is concerned, I do not agree with the suggestion that no notice was taken of any protests made in London. That is not so, because in at least six cases the provisional recommendations were altered as a result of protests made. I think that the constituency of the hon. Member for Islington, North (Mr. Fienburgh) was one.
Not mine, but a neighbouring one.
I beg the hon. Gentleman's pardon. I know that alterations were made. I cannot think of a better case than this one which is supported by the Act.

The curious thing is that the right hon. and gallant Gentleman has now said that what he has previously been calling jiggery-pokery is now part of an Act of Parliament. The right hon. and gallant Gentleman knows that that is nowhere stated in the Statutes. It was taken on the last occasion and accepted by the House as a convenient figure in discussing proposals to say that no constituency should be above it. It was not incorporated in the Act. When it suits the right hon. and gallant Gentleman to explain why Reading is now deprived of a Member he says, "That is what you did in defiance of what the Commissioners proposed."
I think that 80,000 is a convenient administrative figure to take. I am not at all ashamed of having suggested it to the House and it is evident that the Boundary Commissioners have now accepted it as a working rule. Where we go wrong on this occasion is that the first thing we have to consider is the representation of each metropolitan borough. The Rule was not invented by the Labour Government, but goes back to the Redistribution of Seats, Act. 1944. where it is said: No metropolitan borough or any part thereof shall be included in a constituency which includes the whole or part of any other part of a metropolitan borough. That is not one of my wicked inventions. The right hon. and gallant Gentleman says that he has not said it was, but he has been saying it for the whole of the night.

I agree that metropolitan borough is in Rule 4, but surely the right hon. Gentleman and the Government of which he was a member are responsible for the following Rule, which says the Commissioners may disregard that Rule.

I am coming to that. I hope that the right hon. and gallant Gentleman will admit that it did not appear on the Statute Book for the first time in the 1949 Act. It was first inscribed in the Statute Book in 1944. If we could get that admission it would clarify the
atmosphere a bit. The Boundary Commissioners or anyone else examining their proposals with a view to submitting an Order to the House starts the task, I should imagine, by taking each metropolitan borough in succession.
They would find there is one borough, Hackney, which has an electorate of 121,000. That clearly entitles that borough to two seats. That I do not think can be denied as a mere piece of arithmetic. There are two adjoining constituencies. I do not think anyone contemplated, when the matter was dealt with between 1944 and 1949, that three metropolitan boroughs should be brigaded together so that one which was entitled to two seats by itself would get one and two bits, and that the two adjoining boroughs would only get a bit each.
As has been said during the debate, we have in this Order not merely to determine the Parliamentary representation of the areas, but to determine the London County Council representation. I can imagine nothing more difficult than for the ordinary elector in these three boroughs, if this Order is made effective, to discover exactly where he is with regard to Parliamentary elections and his Member of Parliament, his borough council and the councillors and aldermen of that, and the London County Council and the councillors and aldermen of that body.
This makes matters far too complicated. This is a condition of affairs that I do not believe anyone could have anticipated when either of these three Acts was going through. It is another case of the excessive use of saving words which are meant to deal with cases of exceptional emergency. The first mistake was in not recognising the claim that Hackney can assert to have two Members of Parliament in respect of its own internal electorate.
Instead of going back to the fact that these are the Rules for the redistribution of seats, the right hon. and gallant Gentleman is continuously emphasising to us that this is a Redistribution of Seats Act. Certainly it is, and when the Boundary Commission came to do its task the Rules are set out in the Second Schedule. The first Rule, with regard to metropolitan boroughs is: No metropolitan borough or any part thereof shall be included in a constituency
which includes the whole or part of any other metropolitan borough. In each of these three contiguous constituencies that Rule is flagrantly broken. I do not think that one can plead in aid the saving words which are meant to deal with exceptional circumstances only.

I am trying to follow the right hon. Gentleman in his extremely interesting argument. He seems to have left out of calculation two important facts. Assuming that the Borough of Hackney were divided into two constituencies, what would be the size of the electorate in Stoke Newington, and how would it be dealt with? What would be the size of the electorate in Bethnal Green?
I would tell the hon. Gentleman if the figures were available. I have tried to get the figures, but the figures for those constituencies for any year later than 1951 are not available.
Mr. Nabarro rose—

Let me deal with one question at a time. It is a quite frequent request made from the Government side. One of the difficulties that confront us is that that kind of statistic of modern years is not available.

I am grateful to the right hon. Gentleman for giving way. I have been following his argument closely and studying the proposals. As the local government register is the same as the Parliamentary register, and as the fragmentation of Hackney that is complained of is among adjoining constituencies, it should be possible to ascertain the figures for which my hon. Friend asked quite easily, based on the local government electorate for the borough wards.

I agree, but neither are those published by the Registrar General for any year later than the one I mentioned.
Apart from that, when I point out the position of Hackney, it is not incumbent on me, in saying that the Boundary Commission went wrong and that its proposal should have been modified by the right hon. and gallant Gentleman before he submitted them to this House, to discuss at this stage what should be done with the two remaining boroughs. I know from the figures that were quoted tonight that they have larger electorates than Battersea, South, which, in 1954, has
a smaller electorate than 40,000. Therefore, I do not think that that point arises. This is a flagrant abuse of the saving words introduced into the Rules, and it is quite unfair to the electorate and to the administrators in these three boroughs to chain them in this way.
I have endeavoured throughout to be as brief in my interventions as I possibly can be, and, if I am asked a question I try always to reply to it; but I defy anyone, from the figures produced by the Boundary Commission to the House, to provide an answer to the hon. Member for Billericay (Mr. Braine) or his hon. Friend the Member for Kidderminster (Mr. Nabarro).

If the right hon. Gentleman adds up the total electorate for the three divisions proposed in this Order and subtracts the total electorate for the Borough of Hackney given by the hon. and learned Member for Stoke Newington and Hackney, North (Mr. Weitzman), in his most interesting speech, he will arrive at a very remarkable figure for the Boroughs of Stoke Newington and Bethnal Green. In Stoke Newington, for example, the electorate would be no more than 35,000. The whole point of my intervention is to ask the right hon. Gentleman how, if Hackney is divided into two constituencies, as he now proposes, he would deal with a constituency of only 35,000? How does that fit into the Rules?
I think that one would have to look at the other boroughs adjoining Stoke Newington.
Mr. Weitzman rose—

I am sorry, but as I said yesterday, when hon. Members learned in the law attempt to help me in these arguments I generally find that their minds are so clear that they only confuse mine.
I would go as far as to say that it might be necessary to put one ward—possibly of Hackney—into this to level things out, but that would not involve three metropolitan boroughs in an astounding mess-up.

I thank the right hon. Gentleman for giving way, so that I can put this to him. The electorate of the three constituencies proposed has a total
of 196,627; if the total electorate of Hackney is deducted at 121,000, the residual is 75,627, and that would have to be divided between the two constituencies of Stoke Newington and Bethnal Green, giving an average, as between the two, of only 37,800—that is, in round figures; and that, in the opinion of my hon. Friends, is grossly inadequate for a London borough.

I think I can help the hon. Gentleman in so far as Bethnal Green is concerned. In 1954, the electorate there was 40,287 and there is no reason why figures which have been used by the Commissioners elsewhere in London should not be used to make Bethnal Green a constituency on its own. We should then be left with the possible amalgamation of Stoke Newington and Hackney, with not more than one ward of Hackney being required to make a reasonable constituency for Stoke Newington and one ward of the North of Hackney. This would reduce the administrative difficulties for borough councillors, city councillors. Members of Parliament and their respective constituents to a minimum. I do not say that that is the only way to do it but, on the proposition put forward by the hon. Member for Kidderminster, it is not an unfeasible way of handling the situation, and it would be far better than the present proposals.

If that suggestion were followed, the inequality would be that the two Hackney constituencies would each average 60,000—correct to the nearest thousand—whereas the other two would average only 37,500, which would completely offend all the Rules which we have tried to lay down for the Boundary Commission.
The hon. Member has forgotten that I had conceded that it might be necessary to include one additional ward. I am not pleading for any constituency of under 40,000.
Fragmentation.

Fragmentation of somebody is inevitable, but that is no reason why we should have an atomic bomb to achieve it, which is what the Commission has done. To take one additional ward offends, as a general rule, but it is the minimum offence.
Throughout the country there are examples where we have constituencies side by side with 40,000 and 70,000 electors respectively. We find it in Middlesex, in Essex and even in County Durham. Disparities of the kind suggested as a result of this interchange of statistical bargaining between us do not involve precedents, when applied to the whole country.
I believe that the scheme put forward by the Government is thoroughly unsatisfactory. It worsens instead of improves administrative and representative difficulties in the area, and I therefore advise my hon. Friends to vote against it.

The answer to the hon. Member for Billericay (Mr. Braille) is that, although fragmentation would be inevitable here, if our argument were followed there would still be two Members for the Borough of Hackney instead of one.
The point is that what has been done in London could have been understood had there been a pattern. If the Government had said, "We are doing this because this is a very small constituency and must have added to it a number of people from a larger neighbouring constituency," and if that pattern had been followed throughout the country, we could have understood it, but my constituency is small—41,000—and alongside is a constituency of 70,000. The original proposals were that 17,000 of the electorate of that larger constituency should be added to my constituency.
When the second proposal came out they altered it, and said, "All right, you can stay at 41,000." They said to the other chap, "You can stay at 7,000, too." They said it in the case of Battersea, where they had 39,000 in one part and a large weight in the other, with which they had not attempted to interfere. If the Home Secretary had tried to give us some idea where he thought the Commission should have followed the pattern it would have been very interesting. But he did not do that, and he does not know anything about it.
It is a pity that the right hon. and gallant Gentleman did not go out to Australia. They need some stonewallers out there at the moment, because I understand that England has lost two wickets
so far. He would do much better than he has done here. He has merely said, "The Boundary Commission's Report is inevitable and you must accept it." [An HON. MEMBER: "He has had a very long innings."] The whole point of this debate has been that all hon. Members on this side of the House believed that each of these Orders would be discussed on its merits.
It is grouping.

It is rather sad grouping when an hon. Member loses not only his ward but his seat.
We believed that the Home Secretary would get up on an occasional Order and say, "That is fair enough. We think that the case has been advanced and on this occasion we will not continue this Order. We shall withdraw it." But in not one case has he attempted to say that; not one case has been answered by him. He knows nothing about this London argument. In fact, he does not know much about any of them, and after all London, the greatest city in the world, never had an answer from this Boundary Commission.
The Commission had representations. which we have heard, from my hon. Friends, who wrote and said, "These are our representations. May we have an inquiry?" They never even received a card saying, "We have got your representations." None of the political parties were told whether there were to be any changes, and the London County Council were not advised either.
The next thing we knew was that another lot of proposals were presented to Parliament. We all had to dash into the library to try to find out what had happened to our constituencies, and why. I tried to find out why they had altered my constituency back to its former position. As far as I can see, it was because of the borough boundary, and I am glad to know they did it. But they have gone over the borough boundary and given to my hon. Friend the Member for Bethnal Green (Mr. Holman)—or will give him, they hope—a large section of another borough, which is completely contrary to what they said in my case.
The Home Secretary does not attempt to justify it, and does not care. He will see that he does not withdraw this Order because if he followed the argument there
would be another hon. Member here. Why will he not? Because it would be a Labour Member. I believe that our case is so strong for another Member in this instance that the Home Secretary should admit it.
The whole of this debate has developed along this idea: that because the Commission have said it, we have all got to accept it. My hon. Friend said that this is not democracy, it is a mockery. So it is—an absolute mockery. We have been here since yesterday afternoon and on every one of these Orders we have the Home Secretary, with a poor brief, and a Parliamentary Secretary who knows even less, saying, "The Boundary Commission said it and you have got to take it."
The arguments advanced from this side of the House again and again have been completely ignored. That is democracy, is it? Let me say to the right hon. and gallant Gentleman that I think it is a very poor show, not only on his part, but by his party. They say that the Act was introduced by a Labour Government. As was said by my hon. and learned Friend the Member for Stoke Newington and Hackney, North (Mr. Weitzman) this Tory Government were going to show we Socialists how to do the job. When the Act was introduced they said that it was a bad Measure, but they have not done much about it.
If it was so bad, why did not they do something about it? The reason is that it suited them, and they do not intend to do anything about it. [HON. MEMBERS: "What about last time? "] I will tell hon. Members about last time. In London, and here I speak with some knowledge, the Labour Party lost a considerable number of seats. In my own constituency there were two seats and now there is only one with the same electorate; and I had a 21,000 majority, so that we could get another Labour Member in there all right.
The last Boundary Commission Report had to be made because there were so many anomalies. We all recognise that. In this case there was none. But in spite of the case which has been made again and again by hon. Members on this side of the House, the Home Secretary has completely ignored that. Although we have proved that Bethnal Green and Hackney are being treated unfairly, he
still ignores it, and I am glad to know that my hon. Friends intend to vote against this Order.

The Home Secretary acknowledged the unanswerable case advanced by my hon. Friend the Member for Hackney, South, (Mr. H. Butler) by attempting a few sentences in answer to it. In effect, however, all he said was that changes must cause inconvenience, and we were already aware of that. I would remind the right hon. and gallant Gentleman that if changes are necessary, they should be made in a reasonable manner. I do not think that the Minister has any idea of the amount of inconvenience which will be caused by the contemplated change in the Hackney Division.
And he does not care, either.

My hon. Friend the Member for Hackney, South said that his constituents were neither rodents nor nit-wits. They are not crows, either. They cannot fly as the crow flies; they would have to be birds to get to Bethnal Green in a convenient manner. The only way would be to go through my constituency, as Shoreditch and Finsbury adjoin both these divisions.
There is the question not only of the L.C.C. but of the borough elections. These wards are being transferred from Hackney next March. The people will have to vote in the L.C.C. elections in Bethnal Green, and a year later they will be voting in Hackney for borough council candidates. They will belong to Hackney Borough Council—they do not belong to the Borough of Bethnal Green—so they will be supporting Hackney Borough Council candidates in 1956 and going to Bethnal Green to vote for the L.C.C. candidates in 1955. Anything calculated to cause a greater amount of inconvenience it would be difficult to imagine No attempt has been made to answer any query as to why the Home Secretary approved the recommendation of the Boundary Commission to deal with Hackney in this way rather than divide the borough, which has 120,000 electors. into two convenient and full constituencies.
The most frightening thing about this discussion, which has continued for about 13 hours, is that time and again hon.
Members have said, and it has not been denied, that there has been no acknowledgment by the Boundary Commission of communications from responsible bodies and individuals; that there has been no opportunity for discussion or for public interviews and hearings. The Boundary Commission just presented its findings to the Minister and he has presented them to the House, without alteration, in a series of Orders. When the Minister is questioned, he says, "It is not my responsibility. I was not responsible for these things." We are left in the position that the Commission was a body of people we did not know, could not question, and could not see at public interviews.
The Commissioners are responsible for these things. It is a fantastic situation. When we ask the Under-Secretary for information he says that he does not know, that he has a bad memory. To whom can we put these questions? The Home Secretary and his Under-Secretary say that they do not know; they have not the details. They are not expected to have the details. Yet hon. Members and local authorities having the details and wanting to present their views to the Boundary Commission were not permitted to do so. No doubt members of the Commission, within their limited knowledge—and they could not hope to have the intimate knowledge that hon. Members have of their constituencies—did the best they could, but they made a lot of mistakes which could have been corrected if the public hearings which were asked for had been held. This mistake in Hackney could almost certainly have been avoided.
It is astounding that the Home Secretary and the Government should not premit the slightest variation or agree to look at things again. I believe the Home Secretary thinks that London is all alike, that it does not matter if boroughs are out up into bits because the people concerned will unite and be perfectly happy. That is a mistaken conclusion. There are local prides and loyalties which not even the Home Secretary or a Conservative Government will destroy. I was born near the divisions we are discussing. I represent a two borough constituency. Those two boroughs were joined four years ago. There could not be two communities closer than that, yet the people
of these two boroughs are quite different in a number of essentials. It is the same in Hackney. I ask the Home Secretary to realise that this is not a minor inconvenience we are discussing. It will be a major and unnecessary inconvenience for the people concerned. I hope he will look at the matter again.
We have reached this, the nineteenth of the proposed changes for England and Wales, out of a list of 42. The Minister ought now to reveal to the House what are his intentions.
We are dealing with the Order that is now before the House.

I am addressing myself to the Order now before the House. In doing so, I am prefacing my remarks by saying that it is the duty of the Home Secretary to tell us, not only what he is proposing to do, if anything, about the representations made on this Order, but also his intentions about the succeeding Orders.
Devastating criticisms have been made in all cases, including the Bethnal Green, Hackney and Stoke Newington case, from both sides of the House. The outstanding characteristic of the debate on this and previous Orders has been the paucity of contributions in support of the Government by their own backbenchers and by the Home Secretary.
We are entitled to ask at this stage for a clear and unqualified reply about the Home Secretary's intentions and the intentions of the Government. Can the Home Secretary indicate if anything that is said in criticism of this Order and succeeding Orders will carry any weight with him? Is any criticism that can be made from this side of the House likely to alter his present intention of forcing through each of these proposals without amendment? Or is he prepared to listen to reason? If in any case reason does penetrate his mental armour, will he then be prepared to take back such cases for reconsideration?
Can we have a reply to that straightforward question? Has he made up his mind that this series of alterations has to go through holus-bolus without qualification, without amendment? Is there no reply? The answer is that of the Sphinx—absolute silence.

If the right hon. and gallant Gentleman will not respond to that appeal, can I make this appeal to him? When he left the Ministry of Food and went to the Home Office I wished him well and thought that he would retrieve his good name. In this debate he has acted as the public relations officer of the Boundary Commission and has consistently refused to discuss the question of the exercise of the Commission's discretion. I appeal to him in this case to reveal the reasons for the Boundary Commission not receiving representations. It is an exceptional case, because it alters, for all practical purposes, a local government boundary. When local government boundaries are altered, suggestions are made for the alteration and, if an inquiry is wanted, an inquiry is invariably held.

In this case, why has there not been an inquiry? I want to know upon what grounds the Boundary Commission acts without holding an inquiry. Here it is quite clear, as in the Manchester case, that the local authorities and the political parties made representations and, on the face of it—I put it no higher than that—they were entitled to expect an inquiry. No inquiry was held. A great deal of disturbance will take place in the three constituencies. There will be a further disturbance in local government. We are entitled to hear from the Home Secretary the reasons which impelled the Commission not to receive representations in the form of an inquiry and why it did not discuss the matter with those who objected to the recommendations.
Question put:—
The House divided: Ayes 126, Noes 84.

tr.td: Buchan-Hepburn, Rt. Hon. P. G. T.
Crookshank, Capt. Rt. Hon. H. F. C.
Mr. Legh and Mr. Edward Wakefield
Gaitskell, Rt. Hon. H. T. N.

speech.p: Resolved, That the Draft Parliamentary Constituencies (Bethnal Green, Hackney and Stoke Newington) Order, 1954, a copy of which was laid before this House on lath November, 1954, in the last Session of Parliament, be approved.

Motion made, and Question proposed, That the Draft Parliamentary Constituencies (Fulham and Hammersmith) Order, 1954, a copy of which was laid before this House on 18th November, 1954, in the last Session of Parliament, be approved.—[Major Lloyd-George.]

I have sat through the whole of this two-day debate, and what a very heartbreaking business it has been. More than once it has been declared that the Boundary Commission has done a very bad job. Over and over again, not to put the case too highly, hon. Members on both sides of the House have declared their dissatisfaction with what the Commission has done. Some hon. Members have said that they made no attempt to impugn the impartiality of the Commission.
I offer no judgment about its impartiality. What I recognise, however, and what many other hon. Members have recognised, is that, however impartial the Commission may have been, the consequences of its work have been grievously unfair. If not actually contemptuous of public opinion, it completely disregarded any public attempt made to guide it in the conduct of its work.
But perhaps more important than that is the contempt with which Parliament has been treated by the two Ministers in charge of these matters. It is easy, of course, to over-stress one's case, particularly when one is emotionally bound up with the decisions the Government are presenting. On the other hand, I think that no fair-minded person could deny that it is an abuse of Parliament to bring before it Orders and recommendations which, by general acknowledgment on both sides of the House, have been botched up, and to insist on these being discussed through some 15 hours of debate, and to present what I believe to be perhaps the classic example of the Boundary Commission's misspent labours at six o'clock in the morning.
During the whole of this debate, though attacked by Members of their own party as well as by Members on this side of the House, the Ministers have at no time offered any explanation of the reasons that have guided them in offering these propositions for the consideration of the House. They have merely stood up, said that these are the Commission's recommendations, that they are sacrosanct, sat down, and relied, not upon arguments or upon democratic procedure, but rather on the Whips to see that the Members of their own party were brought into the Lobby, of times contrary to their own declared opinions, to vote for the Orders.
On Tuesday last, Mr. Justice Harman said quite clearly about the Fulham and Hammersmith situation that the matter was one for judicial consideration. He said, however, that it was not within his competence to deal with it, because Parliament must act as judge in its own cause. Mr. Justice Harman also added that he was certain that when Parliament came to consider the Hammersmith and Fulham Order, about which he took leave to express some personal doubt, Parliament would see that justice was done. It is obvious that the learned judge is learned in the law, but he has little experience of the conduct of Parliament under a Conservative Government.
The Minister is in a difficult position. All of us on both sides of the House recognise that. He is faced with a situation in which the decision about these Orders was made, so we are told, in Cabinet, so that we in this House have been forced to proceed hour by hour through the farce of trying to persuade the Minister who has not made the slightest attempt to act in a judicial capacity.
For the most part it is manifestly obvious to all of us who have sat in this House and watched that the Minister not only has not attempted to act in that judicial capacity, but for the most part he has not even listened to the arguments. I appreciate the difficulty for the Minister in trying to look like a judge through 15 hours of debate when he is fettered by a decision of the Cabinet about which he can do nothing.
I should like to make this comment and, if it is harsh, it is no more harsh than the occasion demands. The Minister wrote to me as he wrote to others. My borough wrote to him first of all and presented reasoned objections to the conduct of the Boundary Commission in respect of the recommendation relating to Hammersmith. The Minister acknowledged that, which was more than the Boundary Commission did, but he did no more about it. He laid these Orders. My borough again wrote to him asking him to receive a deputation from Hammersmith and Fulham. The Minister said he was not prepared to receive a deputation, although it seemed to me difficult to understand the processes of reasoning by which he said that, because the Orders have been laid, it would have
been improper for him to have received that deputation.
I would have thought it eminently proper for the Minister to have discovered something of the facts of the situation on which he was to act as judge. I attempted to get in touch with him, and I got a reply in which he gave me an undertaking, as he gave other Members, that he would come to this debate prepared to listen to the argument with an open mind and pay careful attention to anything that was said, and that when he heard it he would then make up his mind.
Where is he?
Gone to make up his mind.

Whatever his Ministerial responsibility may be to his Cabinet colleagues, the Minister has been a little less than just in his own personal integrity when he gives an undertaking of this kind and then behaves as he has behaved throughout this debate.
For the purposes of the record, would my hon. Friend quote the reply he received from the Minister?

I have quoted from the letter; I do not want to detain the House too long. I have no hope that anything I say at this late hour will make any more difference to the Minister than the powerful arguments that have already been advanced.
The principles on which the Boundary Commission was required to work are in the Second Schedule to the 1949 Act. Rule 4 lays down that the Boundary Commission shall ensure as far as is practicable that the Metropolitan borough boundaries are not infringed by any changes it may make. It is true that under Rules 5 and 6 the Commission is entitled to break that rule of the sanctity of borough boundaries, if it finds excessive disparity with electorates of neighbouring constituencies or with the electoral quota; or if there are special geographical considerations.
The Minister has been guilty of considerable laxity in the way he has treated Rules 5 and 6. At the slightest difficulty about observing the sanctity of borough boundaries, the Commission was regarded as entitled to take any liberties it liked. Those Rules lay down that
if the position is so serious that it is impossible, without injustice to the general over-all picture or without an offence against the electoral quota, to keep a borough boundary, only then shall strict application of Rule 4 not be made.
Let me examine the conditions laid down in Rules 5 and 6 in regard to Hammersmith. The Minister has talked today in a way that shows he is more politician than judge and as though boundary changes must be made merely because they are recommended. Redistribution has to take place for redistribution's sake. In Hammersmith there is no excessive disparity with the surrounding constituencies or with the electoral quota, when these are compared with constituencies similar to Hammersmith. In 1954 Hammersmith has some 43,000 electorate. Its nearest neighbours are Battersea, North and Battersea, South, Chelsea, Paddington, and Brentford and Chiswick. Then there are the new constituencies of Hammersmith, North, Baron's Court and Fulham. The present Hammersmith, South constituency has an electorate of 43,000; Battersea, North has 43,000; Battersea, South 39,000; Chelsea 49,000; Paddington, North 43,000 and Paddington, South 46,000. Brentford and Chiswick has 43,000 and the only other contiguous constituencies are South Kensington, with 63,000, and the Cities of London and Westminster, with 76,000.
It cannot be held that there is an excessive disparity between Hammersmith, South and its surrounding constituencies when it is remembered that, of those constituencies, some are smaller, and only two are in any degree larger; and in that connection, the disparity between South Kensington and the Cities of London and Westminster is so much greater. Any change in Hammersmith has been a change literally torn out of the general situation and the Boundary Commission has misconceived its function in that it attempts to break through the borough boundary of Hammersmith purely on the grounds that it is permitted to do so by Rule 5.
What is an extraordinary feature about all this is that the Commission, although it has no justification under Rule 5, has committed an attempt on the integrity of Hammersmith's boundaries; although the Commission admits that it is making
this change despite the fact that new alterations will be made in the near future. It is not denied that very shortly all these changes will have to be put again into action because of the movements of population, which are so rapid in the London area.
If, on the other hand, the Government carry out their intention, or their desired intention, of ensuring by some act in the near future that further disturbance or disruption of constituencies shall not be permitted—the Home Secretary has variously used 10, 12, 15 years—then it is a grave injustice to the people of Hammersmith that they should be deprived of their electoral rights and that their boundary should be infringed on the pretext that it is done by the entitlement of Rule 5; because, in fact, no such entitlement has been given to break the primary Rule that the borough boundaries shall not be infringed. Rule 6 states that, even although it may not be the case that there is no excessive disparity in the number of electors, geographical considerations shall apply. I thought that geographical considerations were meant to apply to constituencies such as the Orkneys and Shetlands, or Brecon and Radnor, or similar difficult country areas. If the Home Secretary has felt like it, for political reasons. he has pressed "geographical considerations" into some very odd shapes.
If the Minister is prepared to answer at all, which I doubt, and if he is prepared to give consideration to my arguments, which would be remarkably different from what he has done throughout the debate, he might say that the position of Hammersmith was considered from the geographical point of view. I have looked at the map of the Hammersmith and Fulham constituency to see what kind of constituency has been created by this ruthless tearing of Parliamentary divisions, and the constituency of Barons Court looks to me like a cubist's nightmare, for all the world like some grotesque face with a hand held before it thumbing its nose. That must be one of the reasons which the Home Secretary is using to justify this Order and to justify making this monstrosity of a division called Barons Court.
In the hope that the Minister will at least do me the courtesy which he has so far refused to most hon. Members
and will try to meet argument with argument, I must submit to him that there is very little substance in the reasons which made the Commission propose these alterations. I cannot help feeling that the Commissioners revealed probably more than they intended when they said they had found it difficult to see where they could squeeze one Member out of London. They then chose the four near-small constituencies and were concerned only with mathematical considerations and not with the injury which they were doing to the political and municipal life of London.
For the inadequate reasons, which, without justification, can be torn out of Rule 5, the Commission has broken the primary Rule that no Metropolitan borough shall be made a constituency in which it has to share a part of another Metropolitan borough. The effect of the Commission's Report on the boroughs of Fulham and Hammersmith has been that four wards of Hammersmith, South have been removed to the new Barons Court division, and three wards have been removed to the North Hammersmith division, and the consequence has been the strange picture of a division with ragged edges which I have tried, no doubt inadequately, to describe.
The effects of these recommendations have been far more dangerous and ridiculous than any conceivable advantage which has been derived from them. That the Commission was locked in its private room, dealing not with people or civic considerations but with mathematics of the oddest kind, is to be seen in the fact that the new Hammersmith division has no town hall at all. The town hall of Hammersmith is now in the Barons Court division.
The position therefore is this. The ancient Borough of Hammersmith, which has a continuous history of 350 years, the original hamlet of which was to be seen on the banks of the Thames where Hammersmith now stands as early as the Roman days, has been completely lost, and even the name of that ancient borough has been taken away. It has been renamed by the Boundary Commissioners—who are apparently as unimaginative as they are contemptuous of public opinion—on a site which has no knowledge of history, except as the site of the District Railway Station.
Those are its ridiculous aspects. Some of the effects of the recommendations, on the other hand, have been a serious affront to civic feeling and to historic background of the Borough of Hammersmith. I have already spoken about Hammersmith's ancient date, and that is not a thing lightly to be despised. Hammersmith probably has a local loyalty which, if it is not surpassed in London, is certainly not more than equalled in any other part of London. Purely in terms of its sense of civic responsibility, Hammersmith's record is a very valuable one.
In the General Elections of 1950 and 1951, Hammersmith, South recorded the remarkable vote of 82·1 per cent. of the total electorate. Hammersmith has besides that a remarkable and flourishing social and cultural life that certainly is not surpassed in any other London borough. Most of the people in Hammersmith, if there is a peripheral floating population, have lived there all their lives, their fathers before them, and their fathers' fathers before them. There has grown up in Hammersmith a very strong community feeling, of which the Boundary Commissioners and apparently the Home Secretary—although he ought to be better informed—were apparently completely ignorant.
It is not possible from written representations for the Boundary Commission or the Home Secretary to be aware of the depth and strength of civic loyalty in the people of Hammersmith, for if either the Commission or the Home Secretary were aware of them they would not have done the affront to them which they have done in these Orders and recommendations. There is no continuity of interest between residents of Fulham and Hammersmith. I know nothing about the Borough of Fulham and would not be as presumptuous as the Home Secretary to attempt to legislate for it. I make no comment, therefore, about the respective merits of the citizens of Hammersmith and Fulham, but I do know that the citizens of Hammersmith have no doubt about which is the superior borough.
All their interests are directed and will continue to be directed to different boroughs, and now the situation has come about, not only that they have been linked with "foreigners"—I would
hardly dare call them unbelievers—but that they have had insult added to injury by the fact that Hammersmith, South is now the only London constituency that is not related to a Metropolitan borough and has the other rather doubtful honour of being related only to the Metropolitan Railway.
Perhaps the most important thing of all—and it is something about which one would have thought that the Home Secretary would have been very concerned—is the fact that injury has been done, or will be done, if this Order is passed—and I have no doubt that, owing to the intransigence of the Cabinet's decision, it will be passed—to the administrative structure of the Borough of Hammersmith. I suggest for the consideration of the Joint Under-Secretary—if he is listening to what I am saying—that this is clearly one of the overriding considerations that determined Parliament that Metropolitan borough and county borough boundaries ought not to be transgressed.
Take the situation which will arise in relation to the new Barons Court division so far as it affects Hammersmith. The Member of Parliament for the new Barons Court division and the London County Council members for that new division will find their tasks so immeasurably increased that their difficulties will be almost insurmountable. That applies with more particular force to the L.C.C. members than to the Member of Parliament, but in both cases it puts a severe strain on those representatives which it is little short of an impertinence to put on the shoulders of voluntary workers.
The housing authorities in Fulham and Hammersmith are completely separate. No one who has sat as I have Friday after Friday in a constituency clinic will underestimate the difficulties facing public representatives in trying to deal with separate boroughs within one constituency. When it comes to housing problems, the methods adopted by the two boroughs are entirely different. One borough will be able, perhaps, to build faster than the other, which will increase local resentment. Public health authorities are entirely different. Half the people will have to go to Fulham and half to Hammersmith. The people in the
boroughs will not know and, unless the L.C.C. members and the Member of Parliament are familiar with every street in this hybrid constituency, they will not know to which sanitary inspector the people should be directed. Even the police authority is completely different in these two boroughs. If I may reduce this argument to its absurdity, I would add that even the buses do not run mutually between Hammersmith and Fulham. It will mean that the task of public representatives will be increased tremendously, and for very little reason.
I should be interested to discover how much reading the Home Secretary has done about Hammersmith and Fulham; how much real interest he has taken in the representations made to him in writing. If he has shown as much interest in the written material with which he has been provided as he has shown in the course of this debate, I suggest that he has read nothing about it at all.
A great part of the local rate of Hammersmith is devoted to London County Council purposes. Yet the effect of the Commission's recommendation, and of this Order, if it is pushed through, will be to reduce the London County Council representation which is so important to the boroughs and for which they pay heavily. Through this Order Hammersmith will lose three London County councillors. The task of the London County councillors who thereafter will share responsibility for Hammersmith and Fulham will have to be borne by three voluntary workers instead of six. Difficulties will be created for the administrative machinery, since elections to the London County Council and to Parliament will have to be undertaken in two separate borough organisations.
Ministers ought to be concerned with people rather than with figures, and a matter which should be of primary concern to them is the effect these changes will have upon the residents of the borough, who will have to vote in one place for the borough elections and in another for the London County Council and Parliamentary elections. It ought not to be a matter to which the Home Secretary is indifferent, although it seems to be, that these Orders will not only make a serious attack upon the civic life and traditions of the borough, but will confuse the residents in regard to public
affairs by introducing a new area, the area of Barons Court in particular, which has no relation to any of the functions or districts which are now ascribed for various municipal purposes to the Borough of Hammersmith.
These are cogent arguments. They destroy the basis on which the Home Secretary would claim that ho is entitled to escape from the responsibilities laid upon him by Rule 4. They are not merely my arguments. They are the arguments and objections of every interested body not only in Hammersmith but in the County of London, The protest against the Hammersmith and Fulham Order has been made by Conservative as well as Labour politicians; by Conservatives represented within the joint committee of the Metropolitan Boroughs' Association, and by Conservative bodies within that association as well as Labour; by the London County Council and by Conservative Members of Parliament as well as by Labour Members of Parliament. These objections have been made by every interested body, non-political as well as political, which has any association with Hammersmith. It is a protest which has been made in large numbers not only by public bodies but by distinguished people.
The Home Secretary may have read the letter from a distinguished former member of this House, Sir Alan Herbert, which was published in "The Times." Sir Alan Herbert himself registered his protest against this truncation of the ancient Borough of Hammersmith. He was supported by the son of a former Conservative Member of Parliament who for many years represented Hammersmith in this House, Sir Douglas Bull, son of Sir William Bull. He drew the attention of the Home Secretary to what he regarded as this abuse.
I cannot but believe that if the Home Secretary, or his masters in the Cabinet, or whoever it was who took the decision to have this abominable Order on the Order Paper, had taken the trouble to read these representations, they could not have been indifferent to the wrong that they have inflicted upon the borough and particularly on that Dart of it which I, at least temporarily, have the honour to represent.
All this moving around of 43,000 voters, shuffling them into new areas,
into the truncated new divisions that have no history, is like Melchizedek—has no father and mother and is likely to have no children. To effect one division altering 12 constituencies to a greater or less degree; moving around 43,000 voters; aid this only four and a half years after a major upheaval in London when 19 seats disappeared; only shortly—if the Boundary Commission's view is to be accepted—before it will be necessary to look at the whole matter again, shows that the Commission cannot have behaved with any sense of responsibility to the people of Hammersmith.
The Commissioners have used Hammersmith purely as a way out of the mathematical maze they have created for themselves. The Home Secretary is, or at least ought to be, in a different position. It is his duty, not to his party but to his country, to consider the folly and the injustice of the Commission's recommendations and remedy them by paying attention to the needs of the citizens of this ancient borough. Governments exist for the people. People are not units to be shifted about at the whims of parties who happen to be in Government. I hope—and hope is always triumphant—that the Home Secretary will pay attention to these arguments and withdraw this iniquitous Order.

We have all listened with interest and approval while my hon. Friend the Member for Hammersmith, South (Mr. W. T. Williams) has set forth the claim of that ancient and distinguished borough, which is now to be injured in the way in which it is injured in this Order. There are two essential features about the Order. The first is that it is the one London Order which inflicts on the County of London the loss of a Parliamentary seat. Secondly, this is an Order which departs, not merely from the strict application of the Rule about Metropolitan borough boundaries, but flies flatly in the face of the Rule that Metropolitan borough boundaries should not, in general, be crossed.
My hon. Friend the Member for Hammersmith, South, my right hon. Friend the Member for Fulham, West (Dr. Summerskill), and myself, are therefore entitled, in view of the injury done to the representation in that area and to the borough boundaries, to draw the attention of the House to the claims and
dignity of these two boroughs. Fulham, like Hammersmith, has an ancient history, as is well known. It has for very long been associated with the dignity of the Bishop of London. That dates, I believe, from the time of Bishop Erconwald, shortly before the year 700. He was granted the Manor of Fulham.
That distinguished connection has remained ever since. It has been one of the centres of community life round which the whole community of Fulham has grown. I do not propose to develop that aspect further, as the Bishop's Palace lies not in my constituency but in that of my right hon. Friend the Member for Fulham, West, and she may wish to develop the ecclesiastical aspects of the argument.
It is true that no Metropolitan borough can have had a life as a Metropolitan borough for more than about 50 years, since they all came into being by the same act of legislation, but Fulham as a community is very much older than that. Although the great tide of building that occurred in the 19th century has swept round the older parts of the borough, one does not need a very discerning eye to perceive in Fulham the old parish of Fulham, which is gathered round Fulham Church by the river, the old hamlets of Walham Green and the neighbourhood now called Parsons Green, which have been welded together without losing their individuality and their traditions in the modern 20th century city.
People who are not Londoners are sometimes inclined to label the whole of the suburban area as a dormitory. It would be a profound mistake so to label Fulham. A considerable proportion of its inhabitants work in or near the borough. There is the great generating station, one of the largest in the Kingdom, if not in the world, there is the North Thames Gas Board, there are the industrial establishments connected with chemicals, laundering, and the preparation of foodstuffs, which employ the people of the locality, who live and work near their homes.
Fulham, despite the fact that it is part of the Metropolis, has a real and living community life of its own. It is a community which has not only an economic but a cultural life of its own.
On the map it is not a very large community, yet it can boast some affection for, and some degree of achievement in, the arts, as any of those acquainted with the achievements of its citizens who have contributed to local drama, painting, and the study of history and archaeology, know. We have there a community which can stand up and face comparison with the oldest and most compact in the country. It is not a mere dormitory or a mere slice on the map.
In that part which forms the Parliamentary division of Fulham, East, one is struck at once by the fact that it is a section very suited indeed to be treated as a Parliamentary constituency. Running down it like a sort of spine is the North End Road, starting near Olympia, and then substantially the same road changes its name to Fulham Broadway and Harwood Road until it turns into Wandsworth Bridge Road and reaches the river in the ward of the borough known romantically as Sands End, though the colour of the sand has been somewhat changed by the growth of industry during the centuries from what it must have been in an earlier and less sophisticated stage of Fulham's history.
Round that whole series of roads there run two bus routes. It is possible to travel without difficulty from one end of the constituency to the other in the same vehicle, but that state of affairs will not exist when the place of the constituency is taken by the hybrid constituency of Barons Court. The North End Road is not merely a thoroughfare. As anyone who has visited it will know, it has a considerable street market, and street traders form a lively and vigorous part of the community of Fulham. It is interesting to notice that at one end of North End Road, where the street market is almost at its busiest, there is a centre of municipal and political life.
On an open space near there on many Saturdays during the last nine years there may have been seen and heard the hon. Member for Fulham, East discoursing to constituents and such members of the crowd returning from Chelsea Football Ground as passed by that forum. Not only could the hon. Member for Fulham, East be seen there, but any one of a series of itinerant Conservatives who have endeavoured, without success, to
become the hon. Member for Fulham, East. I believe my right hon. Friend the Member for Fulham, West has had a different but no less humorous series in her constituency.
From that place one might say—although perhaps it is not a very suitable phrase in the circumstances—that only a stone's throw away is the Conservative Club. A little further on is the headquarters of my constituency Labour Party, and not very far away is the town hall. All these political amenities are to be found in the heart of the borough and the constituency. I mention them because the result of the change of boundary will be that instead of being right in the heart of the constituency in future they will be on the extreme edge. The great street market of North End Road, which has always been thought of as part of Fulham, and linked with Fulham Town Hall and Fulham Members of Parliament, will, in future, to its mystification, be told that it is in a constituency called Barons Court.
Is it then the case that Barons Court will have two town halls whilst Fulham will have none?

No, the town hall will remain in Fulham, East constituency but on the extreme edge of it. It will be only a short distance from the Barons Court division. Those who live in that neighbourhood do not think of themselves as being in Barons Court. As a character in one of Bernard Shaw's plays remarked: Denmark Hill is not Camberwell. The Lilley ward is not Barons Court and no one thinks of it as Barons Court.
My hon. Friend referred to the great interest shown in politics and civic life by the people of Hammersmith. I do not dispute that, although I might perhaps point out that the percentage of persons in Fulham, East who voted at the last General Election was 84 per cent. and I think my hon. Friend mentioned a figure of 82·1 per cent. We need not quarrel about that because both are very creditable figures.
In the last few years I have been paid the compliment of visits to the constituency by the right hon. Gentleman the Prime Minister, the right hon. Gentleman the Minister of Defence, the right hon.
Member the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and the right hon. Gentleman the Foreign Secretary, all of whom have tried to persuade my constituents to return someone else to this House for Fulham, East. I was very gratified about all that, and so were my constituents. It made them feel, as journalists say, that the eyes of the world were on Fulham, East. I would not wish to suggest that all those distinguished Members of this House were merely wasting their time. They evidently felt that what happened in that constituency was of some importance, and that it was a constituency worth some attention. I see an hon. Member on one of the back benches opposite who was also, I believe, one of the visitors.
However, to speak a little more seriously, if this Order goes through, in future Parliaments neither I nor anybody else will be the Member for Fulham, East, and the people of East Fulham, whoever they may have wanted as their Member, will, I think, regret that. Anyone who has at any time been associated politically with that constituency will feel regret at the passing from the Parliamentary map of a constituency containing people who took their political duties and responsibilities so vigorously, so seriously, and so cheerfully, because although we take politics seriously in Fulham, we do not take them glumly, nor in a manner entirely devoid of humour.
Now half of this constituency is to be in this unsatisfactory entity known as Barons Court. I believe that in every part of the House we are agreed that it is thoroughly undesirable for a Parliamentary constituency to be nothing but a name and a slice on a map, with no reality. No one can pretend that Barons Court will be anything more than a slice—and a fantastically-shaped slice, as my hon. Friend pointed out—on a map without any sense of unity.
I do not need to develop to the House the really serious inconveniences that will confront the citizens, the Parliamentary representative and the London County Council members of that constituency. Perhaps I should add that the L.C.C. elections occur in the very near future. The passing of this Order will impose a quite unreasonable burden of hurried reorganisation on every political party in that area. It is not reasonable that
people should be expected to reorientate their whole political loyalties and affiliations at such extremely short notice.
It was not at all surprising, therefore, that almost unanimously opposition was voiced to these proposals. The London County Council is a body on which both the great parties in the State are represented. It unanimously, and without distinction of party, condemned this and all the other London proposals of the Boundary Commission.
This is a topic on which my hon. Friend the Member for Hayes and Harlington (Mr. Skeffington) is better informed than I am, and on which I hope that he will say something to the House. I will merely say that the reception given to the London County Council representations by the Boundary Commission was not consonant with the dignity of the L.C.C., or with any reputation that the Boundary Commission may have been trying to build up for itself.
If the right hon. and gallant Gentleman says that it would have been most improper for him to have told the Commission to hold inquiries, we might accept that, but I would ask him, now that we have seen what the Commission has done and what it has failed to do, whether he thinks it right that the Commission should not have sent a 1½d. acknowledgment of the representations received from great public corporations. We should like to know what the Home Secretary thinks of that kind of behaviour. I know that if the right hon. and gallant Gentleman answers, it will be the first time that he has expressed any opinion of his own on any topic since the debate began, but I think that he might at least go as far as that.
The Standing Joint Committee of the Metropolitan boroughs presented the same unanimous decision, the Fulham Borough Council, on which both parties are represented, without a dissentient vote expressed its position. In Fulham, we had the same experience as my hon. Friend the Member for Hammersmith, South had. The Town Clerk, together with the Town Clerk of Hammersmith, made approaches to the Home Secretary, who was asked to receive a deputation. That was seconded by personal appeals by my right hon. Friend the Member for Fulham, West, my hon.
Friend the Member for Hammersmith, South, and myself. We received from the right hon. and gallant Gentleman a letter saying that he would pay careful attention to what anyone might say in the debate. That letter has the right hon. and gallant Gentleman's signature on it, and we have discovered how much the document is worth. Fulham, because of its nature, ought not to have been treated in this way.
What can justify departure from the Rule about not crossing a Metropolitan borough boundary? It must be admitted, both from the Rules themselves and from the special claims of vigorous boroughs like Fulham, that borough boundaries ought not to be crossed unless powerful reasons for doing so could be shown. Strict application of the Rule about not crossing boundaries may be departed from if special geographical considerations, including the particular size, shape, and accessibility, require it. No question of shape or size applies here. The new constituency of Baron's Court is of a ridiculous shape and a muddle of communications.
The only possible justification one might find to show how the Commission's mind worked on this matter of why the Rule about Metropolitan boundaries not being crossed is being set aside, is that the Commission tells us that it is because it has decided that there must be one seat less in London. Why did it decide that? Normally the Commission ought not to cross the Metropolitan borough boundaries unless there are the strongest reasons to justify that action. It has crossed them here, and the real reason is that it had already decided that there must be one seat less in the county.
It reached this decision by taking the electorate of London and dividing it by 57,122, and discovered that the answer was about 42, but had it used as the yardstick, not 57,122, but 55,670, it would have found that London should have 43 seats. If it had stuck to the Act there would have been no need to cross the Fulham-Hammersmith boundary and deprive London of one seat.
What is the excuse for the disregard of the law and of equality? The right hon. Gentleman said that was done in 1947, but he ought to know that is completely irrelevant. This Commission is not, and could not, be bound by anything done or not done in 1947. Its
duty is by the Act which set it up and there is nothing about following rules laid down in 1947. The Act tells it that where it wants a yardstick it is to use the British and not the English yardstick.
The Attorney-General, who intervened in these debates at a point which now seems quite a long time ago, tried to explain the Act by saying that the electoral quota had to be used, otherwise we should get a total number of seats substantially in excess of 613. How much is "substantially in excess"? The Commission proposes to exceed 613 by 5, which is, to the nearest percentage, 1 per cent. It could have avoided all the trouble of using the quite incorrect English electoral quota, the false line of argument which led it to deprive London of a seat, and doing this outrage upon Fulham and Hammersmith, by exceeding 613 by 13, which would have been 2 per cent.
The whole argument for the Order hangs on the view that to increase the number by 1 per cent. is not a substantial increase but to increase it by 2 per cent. is: that is the dogma, the faith which we must hold pure and entire if confidence in the Boundary Commission is not to perish. Does anyone seriously believe that the Home Secretary would say "Yes," if we asked him whether he believed the general proposition, "Are you satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that if the Commission increases the number by 1 per cent. it is not increasing the number substantially, while if it increases it by 2 per cent. it is increasing it substantially"? We have to believe that absurd proposition beyond reasonable doubt in order to justify what has happened in London and Manchester, and is done in defiance of the Rule about the Metropolitan boroughs.
By ignoring the Act and using this bogus English electoral quota measuring rod, the Commission decided to deprive London of a seat, which it ought not to have done. It then had to say, "Where shall we do it?" Any ordinary person, having allowed himself to get as far as that, would have looked first at the smallest constituencies in London, but the Commission looked at Fulham and Hammersmith. Departing from its usual reticence, it tells us why. It was not because those electorates were particularly small, but because the Commission thought that they were going to be small in the future. With an engaging candour,
it admits that anything that happened in Fulham and Hammersmith is quite likely to happen in any other part of London as well.
Instead of speculating about what might happen to Fulham and Hammersmith, why did the Commission not look at what has happened in Battersea, South? There is a constituency which is not only smaller than Fulham or Hammersmith but is the smallest in London. I am not sure that it is not the very smallest one which the Boundary Commission has proposed anywhere in England, below the normal tolerance limit of 40,000. The Commission averted its eyes from it.
By how much is it below?

By 20. I repeat that that is below the tolerance limit. It is the smallest in London, the smallest in England, and yet the Commission has averted its eyes from it, and, by the strangest of coincidences, it is one of the few seats in London which is represented by a member of the Conservative Party.
That, surely, is the complaint—leaving Battersea as it is; but that is probably because the citizens of Battersea make proper representations to the Commission.

If the hon. Member had been awake while my hon. Friend the Member for Hammersmith, South and I have been addressing the House, he would know that full representations were made by Fulham and by Hammersmith. If representations from a Conservative constituency—
I made no representations to the Commission; I was referring to the representations made by the Labour Party of Battersea.

And I was pointing out that representations were made by the boroughs of Fulham and Hammersmith, so that that interruption has nothing to do with the matter.
The original decision to deprive London of a seat is in clear defiance of the instructions given to the Commission, and the further decision as to which borough of London is to be deprived of
a seat is based on no reasonable principle; and instead of having the overwhelming reasons which alone could justify crossing the boundaries of a Metropolitan borough, the Commission has no reason for the most modest infringement of local government boundaries.
The Home Secretary, and the rest of the people responsible for this deplorable procedure, know that all this is true, but do not propose to answer it, any more than they have answered any of the other arguments. What is their frame of mind? Let them turn to the great work of Walter Bagehot, in the middle of the last century, on the English Constitution. He there describes a certain Government Chief Whip who, when a certain matter was discussed in the Cabinet and he had been called in to give his advice as to how a certain matter would be received in this House, replied. "We have a bad case here; we have an indefensible case. We must apply our majority!"
How did he get into the Cabinet meeting?

I dare say that Chief Whips may have been garrulous in those days.
That is the spirit in which this whole major issue has been approached. "We have a case which is bad; which is indefensible" say the Government, and so they apply their majority. But they cannot make what is being done any the more justifiable, nor rub out the fact that the Commission has done its work badly, has been partial in the political sense, and has not respected local loyalties; and now the Home Secretary has made no attempt to explain or excuse what is being done.

I have little to add after the excellent contributions by my hon. Friends the Members for Fulham, East (Mr. M. Stewart) and Hammersmith, South (Mr. W. T. Williams) and I propose to make only one or two short observations. We have had an excellent sociological and geographical survey of Hammersmith and Fulham. My hon. Friends have sought to prove to the House that in Hammersmith and Fulham, in the middle of the 20th century, are
two virile and interesting communities, and they have tried to persuade the Minister that if we approve these recommendations we shall partially destroy those communities. As I heard my hon. Friend the Member for Fulham, East describe conditions in his constituency, which is adjacent to mine, I thought that here was a case to which the Minister should listen.
May I emphasise a personal aspect? We have heard about the factories and the physical conditions in these constituencies, but the Minister will also recall a wonderful Member of Parliament in his time in the House—his family will not mind my mentioning this: I refer to William Banfield, who was the Member for Wednesbury, and who devoted the whole of his political life to trying to abolish night baking. I feel that William Banfield and his family emphasise the point I want to make about community life. He was a constituent of mine in West Fulham.
He had a big family, and he was a fortunate man because, while some families reject the views of their parents and grandparents, his family accepted his views and sought to emulate him. In West Fulham, that family is now identified with every kind of social service. If we ask about the various organisations which are functioning in West Fulham we hear that members of the family are doing their best to promote good causes.
