I met one of the family the other day and asked how things were going, and they told me, to my horror, that if these recommendations are approved the whole family will be out off from Fulham and be in the constituency which my hon. Friend the Member for Hammersmith, South described, with reference to Fulham, as "foreign parts." That is an astonishing thing. Overnight, the Boundary Commission comes along and cuts through what might be regarded as a microcosm of social life in West Fulham. That is another aspect of the repercussions of the Commission's Report.
The Minister has so far been unapproachable in these matters. I think he has failed in this debate, which may prove to be historic, because he has refused to recognise that today and yesterday he should have been fulfilling
a semi-judicial rôle. On each group of constituencies he has more or less reflected the views of the Commission. He has failed to deal objectively with the pleas which he has heard from this side of the House—and some of those pleas have been poignant, for we have heard older men on this side of the House literally plead for their Parliamentary lives. I am sorry that the Minister has not recognised that he should also have listened to these men as a colleague—that he should be here not only as a Minister representing the Boundary Commission and its Report but as a colleague, and that he should perhaps have put himself in the position of some of the men who have pleaded their cases.
Therefore I ask him to reconsider the dismemberment of Hammersmith and Fulham; to weigh up the cases that have been put by my hon. Friends, the Members for Hammersmith, South and East Fulham. We have had, in the last two weeks, a debate on National Insurance, and it seems to me that history is repeating itself. We have had to appeal, time after time, to the Minister to change his mind and to listen more sympathetically, but in the last two days we have failed. I ask the Minister on this occasion to retrieve the situation at this late hour, to look at the matter objectively, and to say that he will reconsider the Boundary Commission's recommendations.

After the three excellent speeches which we have just heard from Members who are personally involved in these changes, I do not want to say very much about the particular proposals, except in so far as they refer to the County of London as a whole. If one looks at the results in London I think they give us almost the supreme example of the folly of the methods adopted by the English Commission. I am not certain whether the West Riding of Yorkshire does not provide an even more grotesque example, but no doubt we shall hear about that later.
It is true to say that all the confusion and uneasiness in London arises from the fact that the English Commission has adopted two processes which are certainly not specifically authorised in the Act, one of which we think, with a good deal of authority, is possibly an illegal one. There is the allocation of a special
and unauthorised quota for English constituencies, and, secondly, there is the division of that quota into administrative counties. There may be some cases where the administrative county does comprise a convenient group of constituencies, but that is certainly not true in London.
London was a statutory creation and was not a growth of natural development. At a particular date, 1888, for certain purposes, boundaries—many of them very inconvenient, awkward, and logically indefensible—were selected. Into that artificial unit there has been divided this unauthorised quota which the English Commision has seen fit to use. Nearly all our trouble in London, Lancashire, and many other places, arises from the combination of these two unauthorised factors.
Earlier, the Home Secretary, in dealing with Manchester said that Lancashire had to lose two seats. But there is nothing in the Act which makes it necessary for Lancashire, or a number of constituencies, to lose seats. That is only the interpretation put on the Act by the Commission and apparently accepted without question by the Home Secretary. It is quite unnecessary, and it is bound to give rise to many anomalies if one diverts this English average into an artificial unit like the administrative County of London.
If one looks at the electorate of London in 1954, it is found to be about 2,391,000. If one divides the London electorate by the specified statutory quota for Great Britain of 55,670, one gets an answer of 43, which corresponds with the existing number of seats. If that is the case, and in view of the widespread changes which took place only a few years ago, why was it necessary for the Commission to create all this dislocation in London after such a short period? We need not have any of the arguments about the size of Hackney and Stoke Newington if the Government would leave well alone.
If we are to apply a measuring stick, and if we use the proper quota and divide it into the London electorate, we get the answer of 43. Why mess about with it? We can only get an answer to reduce if we take a quota which is not authorised. The effect of these Orders, if they go through—and I still hope that
the Home Secretary will show, for the first time, that he is not a slave to the recommendations of the Commission—42 seats in London will have an average electorate of 56,935. Yet the quota authorised by the Act is 55,670. The net effect is that there will be 300 electors per London constituency more than the average for all the English constituencies together—both borough and county, of 56,564.
That is quite unjustifiable. Indeed, were it not for the fact that the Commission was here dealing with a large area and a large number of constituencies, it could not so have maneouvred its recommendations that one seat was lost. In the smaller counties it could not be done. Take Cumberland, for example, where there are four small seats, each with an electorate of 47,000, or about that. They cannot be reduced by one, or else there are created three seats, each with an electorate of 67,000.
Again I must point out to the House, as I tried to do some 26 hours ago with reference to the country as a whole, that these proposals, which originally affected 22 constituencies in London—they are now, I am glad to say, slightly modified—are suggested only four years after the last comprehensive changes in London. Then 19 constituencies disappeared, and the unhappy infringement of the Metropolitan boroughs started. I regretted that when it started in 1948. I said so at the time, both in this House and outside.
Having regard to the history of London; the position of the capital centre of the Commonwealth, and to local government complications in London, which are very great, this merging of Metropolitan boroughs was unfortunate and unworthy, and was bound to lead to acute difficulties—as in fact it has done. Anyone who has taken part in a Parliamentary election in which two Metropolitan boroughs are concerned will realise the kind of complexities which arise. What happened four years ago? Not only did 19 seats disappear, but eight of the Metropolitan boroughs which were self-contained up to that time were affected.
Shoreditch and Finsbury were amalgamated, and three boroughs had pieces of them knocked off and put into other boroughs. Bits of Chelsea went to
Kensington. The whole of Holborn went with bits of St. Pancras, and bits of Stoke Newington went to Hackney. The effect of that was felt only four years ago—such a short period in the political life of a nation. Then 48 of the then 62 existing constituencies were changed.
One would have thought, having regard to those widespread changes, that whatever the Commission had recommended, the Home Secretary would have considered whether it was necessary to impose this further dislocation on London, with all the other complications of the London County Council electoral divisions. I do not suppose there is a case in law or logic for treating London differently from anywhere else; but one could at least have said that here was a case for the status quo in view of the widespread dislocation so recently created. Now four more London boroughs are to be put into the unfortunate position of having their boundaries merged in one way or another, so that north of the river 13 out of the 19 Metropolitan boroughs will have their boundaries infringed. That seems to show tremendous indifference to London's feelings, and to the representations made.
Even at this stage I hope that the Home Secretary will reconsider this case, especially in view of the anomalies which remain. If he could say that he had got rid of some very large and very small constituencies in London he would have a case which could be argued; but that has not happened.
Large and very small constituencies are left, for instance, Battersea, South, to which reference has been made, with under 40,000 electors, and Hampstead, with more than 70,000. It is perhaps accidental that they are Conservative seats. The number of small constituencies which remain shows that the tidying process, for which there might have been some justification, does not exist. The changes are unnecessary, and do not remove differences which exist in the size of London constituencies. I do not know whether there is any other case where protests have been so unanimous as in London. Though it is not altogether popular with all hon. Members opposite, the London County Council is the largest municipal government in the world. It is composed of members who make no bones about their politics in the council
chamber. It is a controversial local authority if ever there was one. Yet it was unanimous in opposing the provisional and the final recommendations of the English Commission.
When the draft Orders appeared, the following resolution was put on the council's order paper, and was carried by members of the majority and the minority parties: That in relation to the Draft Orders which had been laid before Parliament to give effect to proposals contained in the first periodic report of the Boundary Commission for England, set up under the House of Commons Redistribution of Seats Act, 1949, the Council is of opinion that the reasons given by the Commission justify neither reduction of Parliamentary constituencies in London from 43 to 42 nor any departure from the injunction contained in the Act that so far as practicable no Metropolitan borough or part thereof shall be included in a constituency which includes the whole or part of any other Metropolitan borough. That was passed in the council with complete agreement.
That is a remarkable example of unanimity in a body which does not hesitate to be very controversial on issues when it feels that to be the right course. My hon. Friend the Member for Fulham, East (Mr. M. Stewart) referred to the Metropolitan Boroughs Standing Joint Committee. All the 28 Metropolitan boroughs are represented by both parties, and that committee has also recorded its unanimous objection to these recommendations. Political parties—certainly the Labour Party, and, I understand, the Conservative Party—in London have also made objections. In addition, many various individuals, representives of both parties, have made representations to the Commission against these proposals.
Surely, in face of this unanimous opinion of municipal London and of public life of London, the Home Secretary is not going to give the same monotonous kind of reply that we have heard up to now. If he does, we really shall feel—as has been suggested, although I still hope that it is not true—that a good deal of this debate is sheer farce and unnecessary, because the Home Secretary is not listening to the arguments and is really not prepared to consider them.
I must again refer to the effect on the London County Council elections. I raised the point yesterday. No reply has yet been given, although it may be that
the right hon. and gallant Gentleman was taken by surprise. If that be the case, he must have been badly advised by his officers about the position in London. The London County Council is responsible for organising the county constituencies. The alteration of registers now in course of preparation, the redefining of polling areas, and the resiting of polling booths will be the necessary results of this change, if these proposals go through. This will place a good deal of administrative work on the council.
In addition there is the difficulty for the political parties. They must, if they are to fight an election, re-constitute the new constituency: new management committees have to be informed and candidates adopted. To expect all that to be done in three months with any degree of efficiency is expecting almost the impossible. There is no reason why the great elections of London, which take place every three years and are extremely important politically, should suffer because of the incompetency of the Boundary Commission.
Whatever is the result, I hope that the right hon. and gallant Gentleman will still be prepared to look at the London county constituency position. Even if he does not do so, we should like to see some kind of standstill agreement for the county constituencies of London. I hope that we shall have at least the courtesy of a reply from the right hon. and gallant Gentleman. We have not had it so far. This matter was raised 25 or 26 hours ago. Not the slightest notice has been taken of a point which seems to be of greatest importance.
I hope that the right hon. and gallant Gentleman, who has so far made "No, No, Nanette" look like a "yes-woman," will agree to some modification in the Orders. They are his Orders, and he has the right to do that. We have not had a single concession. I hope at this late hour that we may get some proof that this debate has not been a complete farce, with the matter already decided without any consultation at all with the House of Commons.

My right hon. and gallant Friend and I have heard every word of this debate, and I will try and answer the numerous points that have been made, but I think that it is impor-
tant to put the general principle into proper perspective.
In this case, the recommendations of the Commission, on which the Order is founded, are dealt with at some length in the Report of the Commission. Hon. Members will of course have carefully read paragraph 18 of the English Report. Certainly, the hon. Member for Fulham, East (Mr. M. Stewart) has done so. Indeed, he went almost to the length of accepting these recommendations, subject to—and I agree that this is a very important proviso—the fact that he disagreed with the principle on which the Commission applied the electoral quota.

The exceptions I took to that were two. First, I made it clear that the Commission had not justified the case for reducing seats in London and, secondly, even if it had, it had not justified its Choice of area in London. Apart from that, I have no objection to 18, but there is not very much left.

I want to narrow the issue and to see where we stand. I will try to deal with these two points. They are very important and, indeed, they have been made on nearly all the arguments on the various Orders. I should like to say something at greater length than has been said hitherto on the subject of the use of the electoral quota.
Exactly the same question existed in 1947. The Great Britain quota was then 57,697, but the English Commission based its proposals on the English average, which was 59,312. That is stated in paragraph 9 of the 1947 Report. It is stated quite clearly, so it was known to the House and certainly to the then Government. The changes made in 1948 had the effect of reducing the English average to about 56,755—less than the quota—but it also reduced the Great Britain average to about 55,630. Consequently, in 1953 the Great Britain quota was 55,670—less than the English average of 57,122. So far there is no dispute between us.
In exactly the same way, if England were now given 13 more seats instead of only five, this would bring the English average down to the 1953 quota, but it would mean that the quota in operation at the next review would again be sub-
stantially below the English average. The same point would arise again. On the Opposition's argument England would once more be entitled to another 10 or 12 seats. This process would continue general review by general review. In other words, what the Opposition is saying is that we ought under the Act to go on adding steadily to England, and to England alone—
No.

That is the effect of the argument—10 or 12 seats at every review. Clearly that is not the intention of the 1949 Act. On the contrary, the limit on the number of seats under Rule 1 is plainly designed to prevent this very thing from happening.
It has been argued that 13 seats would not now be a substantial increase. The right hon. Gentleman the Member for South Shields (Mr. Ede) and other hon. Members have argued that. The principle if it were applied—and if it were applied at all it would have to be applied in all cases—would mean not simply this single increase of 13 seats but a continued increase of 13 or some such number at each review.
Mr. William Warbey (Broxtowe) rose—

This is a difficult and technical matter. Perhaps I may be allowed to finish my argument and then the hon. Gentleman might put a question. Clearly at some point a line must be drawn between what is and what is not substantially greater than the statutory figure. From all these considerations it is clear that the only sensible and logical view of Rule 1 is that taken by the Commission on the last occasion and on the present occasion. Indeed, that was the view which hon. Members opposite took when they were responsible for operating the Act.

The hon. Gentleman is arguing that we must not increase the number of seats by 13 this time because in certain circumstances we would have to make further increases next time, but what the Act talks about is the conclusions reached now, not what may happen in a few year's time. The whole argument rests on certain assumptions as to comparative populations in England, Scotland
and Wales in five year's time. The whole thing is hypothetical from beginning to end.

Of course the whole question of redistribution is hypothetical. [HON. MEMBERS: "No."] We have to proceed on a hypothesis, and I would proceed on the hypothesis recommended by the Commission—[An HON. MEMBER: "Why not on the figures?"]—and accepted by the Government.

May we take it from what the hon. Gentleman has said that he expects, as far as the present review is concerned, that the figure of 13 is not substantially greater than that provided in the Rules and that, having accepted that, the criticisms made by my hon. Friends throughout the night on the present Orders have been entirely justified?

I certainly do not agree with any of that. My whole argument has been that the principle on which hon. Members opposite argue that 13 is the right figure would involve a much larger increase again and the proper course for the Government to take is the increase recommended by the Commission by operating the Rules in the only way considered reasonable by all who consider them in a dispassionate spirit.

This is a very important point, and this is the first time we have had any real discussion on it. The hon. Gentleman is saying that if we apply the Rules as the Commission does, every time there is a review of English constituencies there will be a reduction. It is just as absurd to say that as to say that there is bound to be an increase.

I do not know how the hon. Member counts—perhaps he does it backwards. No doubt on future occasions there will be similar movements; there may be a slight increase or a decrease. I think I have dealt fairly and fully with that substantial point.
Littlewoods are not in it with the hon. Gentleman.

The hon. Member for Fulham, East put another point perfectly clearly, that even if we have to make a reduction of one why pick on that particular constituency? Here there are four adjacent constituencies, the two Fulhams and two Hammersmiths—
All Labour.

The electorates in each of these constituencies are: 44,600, 44,800, 41,200, and 42,900. They are a group of constituencies all of which verge on the minimum level. The hon. Member says they are all Labour constituencies. Is he making a charge against the Commission?
It is the Government's Order.
The charge is against the Government.
This Order is based on the recommendation of the Commission—
Will the hon. Gentleman allow me a moment?
I will not.
We are charging the Government.
The hon. Member for Fulham, East asked why we chose these constituencies. We chose them because they were recommended by the Commission.
The Government are responsible.
What about Battersea, South with 39,000, which is Tory-controlled?

The hon. Member for Hammersmith, South (Mr. W. T. Williams), who began this debate, referred in particular to Rules 4, 5 and 6. He suggested that my right hon. and gallant Friend had always allowed Rules 5 and 6 to prevail wherever possible. He and other hon. Members suggested that Rules 5 and 6 ought not to prevail unless it was necessary for them to do so.
If hon. Members will read these Rules, they will see that the operative word used in each case is not "necessary," but "desirable." In Rule 5 they will see it stated: a Boundary Commission may depart from the strict application of the last foregoing rule if it appears to them that a departure is desirable to avoid… Therefore, it is obvious that it is not intended that there is to be any such high test as suggested by hon. Members opposite.
The hon. Gentleman also raised the novel point that the result of amalgamating the parts of the two boroughs to make the single constituency would mean that the Member would have to deal with more than one housing authority, and he suggested that that would give rise to a great deal of extra work for the Member.
I do not know whether he appreciates that practically every Member of a county constituency has to deal with up to half a dozen or more local authorities. Perhaps he has never bean a Member for a county constituency, but it does not come well from hon. Members to argue that there is no reason at all for giving county Members a rather smaller number of electors to deal with. I think that I have dealt with all the points that have been fairly raised in this debate, and I hope that the House will approve the Order.
Surely the hon. Gentleman will say something both about the united representations in London and the question of the county constituencies of London.
The point about the united representations has been made a very great number of times.
What is happening to them?

It is pretty obvious that everybody objects to having constituencies taken away from them, whatever their politics, whether they are Members of Parliament or members of local authorities. It really cannot be said that one should never take action merely because of the unanimity of objection. If that were the test, it is perfectly plain that the whole of this Act would be abortive and that every Redistribution Act would be abortive, because, as I say, everybody objects to having their constituencies redistributed.
I think that the hon. Gentleman also complained about the shortness of the period before the L.C.C. elections. It is true, of course, that there will only be some three months, but here there was a choice of evils. Either we had to have this relatively short period—it really should not be too short for what is not really a very complicated piece of organisation—or the alternative was to leave the matter, not for a matter of
months, but for a further period of three years. On the whole, it seemed wiser, better and fairer to deal with the matter as the Government have done rather than to leave it over for three years.

I will not stand long between my hon. Friends who wish to speak and the House, but I think all of us who have been present during the debate, and certainly during the performance we have just had from the Under-Secretary, will have been struck by the complacency with which he produced the brief which had been prepared for him. It is astonishing that, after we have had two full days debate, followed by a whole night, it is only now at this hour of the morning that any real excuse has been produced by the Minister to explain and try to substantiate these Orders. It is astonishing not only that we should have to wait until now, but that when we get the explanation it is so poor.
The Under-Secretary did not explain why the Home Secretary has seen fit to foist these Orders on the House without attempting to mitigate the damage the Commissioners have done, although a strong case has been made against them. The seats in London are to be reduced from four to three, and to add insult to injury one of the remaining constituencies is to be named after an Underground railway station. The area is to be robbed of three London county councillors and its representation will be reduced by that number.
We think that the right hon. Gentleman should have taken note of the objections raised, particularly as he is empowered to do so under the Act. As I sat here and watched the faces of hon. and right hon. Gentleman opposite, I wondered what they would have done if they had been sitting on this side, and they had been under the impression that these changes would make an adverse difference to them electorally when the next General Election came. Whether the changes will help them or not, I do not know, but I gather they imagine they will help them and for that reason are accepting them with complacency and without attempting to get the Minister to change his mind. If anything like this had happened in earlier days, the Minister would have risked being charged by outraged Members with attempting to
rig the forthcoming election in the interests of one political party. What a contrast we have here with 1948.
I should like to feel that hon. Gentlemen opposite are ashamed of what is happening now. Then, in London alone the Government reduced the number of seats by 19, thus robbing the Labour Party not only of representation in this House but representation on the London County Council as well. That was in marked contrast to what is happening now. Here the plain facts are that London electors number 2,425,167 and have been allotted 42 seats. Their quota was 43·563, or in other words 44 seats. No one can dispute that London at the present time is under-represented by two seats. We cannot see why those two seats should not now be given to London by the Home Secretary.
The attitude of the Minister has rarely been equalled in this House. I am astonished at the way in which the right hon. and gallant Gentleman has conducted himself in this debate. He seems to have made no attempt to go through the list to see which of the Orders were justified and which ought to be amended in the interests of decency and democracy. He has accepted them as they were given to him and has presented them without much explanation; such explanation as has been given has, in any case, been the same every time. It has been a poor explanation, given with not much spirit. The only time we have seen any animation at that Box was when the hon. Gentleman read out just now the brief which had been supplied to him, after much effort and after such a long time. I am sure that when this debate finishes my hon. Friends will go into the Lobby with the utmost alacrity to show what we think—and what the country will think—about the actions of this Government in this matter.

When, about three hours ago, we were discussing Orders relating to Manchester, the Government benches contained some worthy representatives of the Conservative Party in Lancashire and district. Two hon. Ladies on the Conservative benches had the courage to go into the Lobby in opposition to their Government, and at least two Lancashire M.Ps. abstained. We have been discussing since half-past
five the situation in London, and only three Tory M.Ps. were at any one time on the Government benches representing London constituencies.
The reply which the Joint Under-Secretary of State has just given, and his faulty reading of what must have been a badly cyclostyled brief, have not produced a single protest from the London Tory M.Ps. That is an evidence of the decadence of the Tory Party in London. That is one of the reasons why London is a Socialist city and why it will continue to remain a Socialist city.
The Under-Secretary of State used the Report as a shield for his defence—a Report which is confused. The hon. Gentleman cannot make up his mind whether the investigations into this situation will lead to an increase or a reduction in the number of seats. If he will refer again to paragraph 18, he will see that the last paragraph is: We are not unmindful that alterations in the distribution of the electorate in other areas in London may, within a comparatively short time, render other changes of boundary necessary. What does "comparatively short time" mean? Does it mean the sort of time which has elapsed since the last rearrangements were made and the present proposals?
It is an important point because every single word which has been uttered in defence of this doctrine has come from this document. But the Home Secretary told the House yesterday, that it was his wish that there should not be a rearrangement in London for many years; so, what are we to believe? Do we accept the words of the Home Secretary or the statement in this document? We cannot go on with this confusion, and we cannot sit all through another night as frustrating as this has been.
I have the honour to represent a constituency which is not affected by any of these proposals, and that is something which I cannot understand. I cannot understand why Deptford has not been touched. It is a historical borough it has a long history, in which it is on common ground with Fulham and Hammersmith; and it is a borough known throughout the world. Just as Hammersmith was made famous by the Palais de Danse, so Deptford was made famous by Drake.
I gathered that Deptford is not affected by this Order.

That is so, Mr. Deputy-Speaker, and I am asking why it is not affected. What are the reasons for the fact that the two boroughs of Fulham and Hammersmith have been so treated, while Deptford has not.
There are discrepancies in the London plan, and we have tried to get an explanation from the Under-Secretary as to how these discrepancies arise. Deptford is one of the 111 constituencies with between 50,000 and 55,000 electors, and it is within four per cent. of the electoral quota. It is a small constituency, tucked up tidily, with a town hall and local administrative offices, and it is geographically homogeneous, as are Fulham and Hammersmith. Furthermore, it is a Labour seat "as safe as houses." Therefore, I cannot think why there is no change.
Deptford could not be changed to make it a Tory seat.

My hon. Friend knows better than I do, and at least I have an answer, which is more than I shall receive from the Government front bench.
This is a Government of traditionalists who decide that they will change the name of a constituency famous throughout the world for the name of a railway station. What would happen if we on this side of the House sat where the Government are today and we sought to change the name of Ascot or Goodwood, or wanted to call Eton by the title "Fenner Brockway"? We should be told that we were destroying some of the sacred institutions of this country. This change, which will be railroaded through in a few minutes, is a piece of folly and an insult to the people of London, and so that we may have a monument to this folly and this incredible stupidity, I recommend the Government to change the name of the new constituency to Baronet Court.

In view of the fact that the Joint Under-Secretary of State reserved his attempted reply to one of the main arguments until the end of the proceedings, it is right that I should make some comment on it. At the beginning of his speech we thought for a moment that he was about to attempt what he has never
attempted in all his previous interventions—that is, to debate the issue. He very soon discovered the unwisdom of that course, however, and after he had attempted the explanations, we could all understand why he had not attempted them before.
In the course of these abrupt and abbreviated explanations, he gave away a large part of the case which the Commission was supposed to have represented to us in previous debates, because his main contention was that we had to take some hypothetical figures—not merely the figures at the present time but hypothetical figures at the time of a subsequent review. If that is the case, it disposes of the argument put up by the Government on a variety of individual Orders, for they have argued that we cannot take into account the development which may take place two or three years hence, but must consider only the figures on the register at present.
I can understand why the Government have got into such a mess, because the Commission has pushed them into it. The Commission has indicated a principle which it has applied here but has refused to apply in most other cases—the principle of saying that The evidence available to us indicated that the trend of the comparatively low electorates contained in the present constituencies had to be taken into account. By what right does the Commission take into account the trend of declining electorates in this area when it has consistently refused to take into account the trend of declining or increasing electorates in the case of almost all the other Orders?

The Joint Under-Secretary said that the reason for all these mathematics to deprive London of a seat was that in future there would be more people in London, compared with Scotland and Wales. The Commission Report tells us that Fulham and Hammersmith must lose a member because in future there will be fewer people. It seems that whichever way we assume the trend, the number of Labour seats must be reduced.

I am sure that Lord Woolton has put the matter quite as succinctly as my hon. Friend. He made a speech only a few months ago in which he indicated that.
I was dealing with the general principle to be divined here, which has been applied in Fulham and Hammersmith. If applied elsewhere, it could have enabled the Government to alter the Commission's proposals. But the fact is that when it suits the Government to apply it they do so, and when it suits them to apply it in another way, they follow their instincts in that direction, too.
This is a serious matter for the City of London. It is quite clear from the principles which have been applied to the City of London in this case that if there is any basis for any of the mathematical calculations defended by the Minister, there was an overwhelming case for the population of the City of London and—
The County of London.

Perhaps the hon. Member for Battersea, South (Mr. Partridge) is envious of the even lower electorate which they had in the City of London. We were promised that one of the major points of legislation to be introduced into Parliament would be the restoration of the university seats and the seats for the City of London. That is one of many promises which, for excellent reasons, have not been kept.
The fact is that this is a very serious matter. The application of this principle to London proves that every time there is a Boundary Commission Report and boundary changes, London will be involved in large-scale convulsion, because it is a wide area, and that it is possible for this butchery to be carried out in a fairly easy way in London. In this case, London will be subject to this process every two or three years, if these principles are accepted, and that is a very serious matter.
We have had no reply in the whole debate as to why the Cabinet made the

decision a few days ago that they would drive these Orders through without any possibility of amendment and modification. I have been searching for the last two days to discover what is the answer, and I think that possibly I have hit on as good an explanation as we are likely to get, at any rate from the Government itself or any spokesman.

I have been trying to calculate what are the electoral quotas of all the members of this Cabinet who have made the decision. I looked up the names—I think they came to about 14—and discovered that there are only two members of this Cabinet whose figures are above the electoral quota, and 12 members who are well below the electoral quota, and that the average for the members of the Cabinet is about 50,000 per constituency. That is leaving out the Members of the House of Lords, for if one put them in, that would reduce the figures still further.

Therefore, the men who have made this decision to hack about all these constituencies and take no account of the protests from the constituencies themselves, are themselves representing, on an average, constituencies well below the quota. Naturally they have an interest, which they should have declared at the beginning, in protecting the smaller rural county constituencies against the urban constituencies. I am not saying that this is the final and conclusive reason why the Cabinet reached this decision, or that they decided this solely on the interest of the members who happened to be there at the time. I am not saying that is the reason, but until I get some explanation from the Government I do not see why I should not believe in that reason as well as any other.
Question put:—
The House divided: Ayes 123, Noes 74.

Crookshank, Capt. Rt. Hon. H. F. C
Mr. Wills and Mr. Robert Allan.
Gaitskell, Rt. Hon. H. T. N

speech.p: Resolved, That the Draft Parliamentary Constituencies (Fulham and Hammersmith) Order, 1954, a copy of which was laid before this House on 18th November, 1954, in the last Session of Parliament, be approved.

speech.speakername: The Lord Privy Seal (Mr. Harry Crookshank)
speech.p:
I beg to move, That this House do now adjourn.
I hope that the hon. Member who has the Adjournment will excuse me for moving this Motion. We have not finished this business, as I had hoped we might, and as their was every indication in the earlier part of the day that we might. We have reached the time when in my opinion, and in the opinion of my colleagues, it is no longer suitable
for the House to be sitting. [Interruption.] I must inform the House that, not having got this business at this sitting, it will involve reconsideration of next week's business. I cannot at the moment say what that might involve. I will make a statement about next week's business sometime during the sitting today.

I apologise for the few minutes or so which I may take. I am not sure who has won so far, but I accept the right hon. Member's Motion in the spirit in which he has moved it. [HON. MEMBERS: "What is that?"] That is what I am trying to find out. We are willing to go on. The way in which this Motion has been moved precludes any Division on it.
It is the only way it can be done.

The next Order could have been called and the adjournment of the debate then moved. That would have given an opportunity to discuss it without entrenching on anyone's time. [HON. MEMBERS: "Withdraw."] He cannot withdraw it now. The right hon. Gentleman has indicated that he will make a statement later in the day. I will see that there is someone available to ask the appropriate question when the time comes. I hope it will not be at 11 a.m.
It certainly will not.

Does not the right hon. Gentleman think it unfair to ask the House to agree to the adjournment without indicating whether the Government will give time during the day or at mid-night next week? What about the consequences for Yorkshire and other areas in Orders very far down the list? Will they be taken at a late hour of the morning?

We are entitled to know more about the situation. We have already sat through a whole night and part of this morning to try and urge upon the Government some proper reconsideration of matters which affect not merely political parties but our whole system of Parliamentary democracy. It is a matter for the House as a House and not for the Government as a Government. We are being asked to make time for Government 'business. If the Government are concerned about the way in which the electors are represented in the House—which is what we have been discussing—it could be discussed if this Motion were withdrawn. The House would then be in charge of the matter and we could give time to it before the Christmas Adjournment.
The Government are trying to find time before Christmas to push through legislation which is not required. We can very well do without this legislation and bring it forward again after Christmas. There is no reason at all why the debate on these Orders should not be finished today. I hope that the right hon. Gentleman will look at this in the spirit of regarding the House as a collective assembly and not as a Government and an Opposition.
Why all this fuss about Christmas? It is not celebrated in Scotland and Scottish Members do not see why these Orders should not be considered until the New Year.

We must protest at the way in which the House has been treated. I can say only that I hope that one of the consequences of this adjournment may be that the right hon. Gentleman will persuade his Cabinet colleagues, particularly in view of the remarks made by my hon. Friend the Member for Devonport (Mr. Foot), to think about this matter so that we may have a very much more extensive reply from the Government.

There is another point, and that is the unfairness to those constituencies whose case was not considered last night, or this morning. Quite a number of these oases remain to be considered, and it is invidious that they should be singled out for neglect. We should continue consideration of this matter so that those Orders not yet reached can be discussed before the House adjourns. One remarkable feature of the discussions last night and this morning has been the shocking way in which the Government have sought to make the House delegate its authority. It was a matter for the House fully to consider.
We are disgracefully being asked to adjourn without completing the work to which we have set our hand. That would be bad enough in itself, even if it were not that to adjourn now would inflict a grievous wound upon those constituencies in the list which have not been reached. No self-respecting Government would ask the House to do a thing of that kind. I appeal to hon. Members who have had the courage and the stamina to remain here all night—as we have—to remain here a little longer and complete the work to which we set our hand last night.
It would be disgraceful for the House to confess failure now, at 25 minutes to nine, after having sat continuously for all these hours. After all, it is a minority of constituencies which still remain to be considered. Why should not we deal with that minority? Why should we be invidious in this matter? We have
enough Members here to go on with the business of the nation. It is a minority of the House, it is true. A number of hon. Members appear to have run away or fallen by the wayside, but there are some strong and courageous souls still remaining. I appeal to hon. Members, not only on this side of the House, but opposite,
to show their courage and willingness to go on with the business of the nation.
I hope that the Motion will not be accepted—that the House will reject it.
Adjourned accordingly at Twenty-three Minutes to Nine o'Clock a.m.
